extended_text.content:
In 1940, after 12 years of designing for Hattie Carnegie, Norell joined clothing manufacturer Anthony Traina and launched one of the most successful fashion lines in the United States. Norell was the first American fashion designer to have his own name on a dress label.

This classic shirtwaist dress, executed in a geometric diamond pattern of bold colors, is an early example of Norell’s emphasis on designing simple, elegant, and well-made clothes. The short-sleeved fitted bodice with lightly padded shoulders has self-fabric button closures in the front, as well as a side zipper. The neckline is finished with a narrow band that ties in a bow at the front.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

2746.exhibit_history:
An American Legacy; Norell, Blass, Halston & Sprouse
Paul Textile and Fashion Arts galleries, IMA
May 4, 2012 - January 27, 2013

54833.title: Yellow Mobile Parabolic Arc
54833.title_notes: Note that this sculpture appeared in Masters of Contemporary Glass, p. 13, fig. 1, with the title "Mobile Yellow Parabolic Arc"; however, the sculpture entered the collection and has consistently been cataloged with the title "Yellow Mobile Parabolic Arc." The latter order appears to be correct and is in line with how other Littleton arc sculptures are named, with the color appearing as the first word. (Rebecca McNamara, Curatorial Coordinator, Luce Digitization Project, 2015)
54833.description: Hot worked glass, barium/potash glass with mulitple cased overlays of Kugler colors sitting on a colorless hot worked rectangular base
54833.credit_line: Gift of Marilyn and Eugene Glick
54833.inscription:
Dated and signed, interior side of arc, near flat edge: 1981 © Harvey K Littleton
Signed and dated, near bottom, along curve of arc: © Harvey K Littleton 1981
54833.current_location: David and Anne Knall Gallery Art Storage Room (H204.2)

extended_text.content:
In this painting, Prendergast handled watercolor with his characteristic freedom, wielding thin washes in loosely knit strokes and allowing the white paper to become part of the composition. Contemporary critics noted that Prendergast’s loose style fit his leisurely subjects.

The artist often painted scenes of people enjoying New England’s waterfronts, piers, and promenades. Prendergast’s focus may have been influenced by his earlier studies in France, where he was exposed to French Impressionist visions of modern leisure.

Gloucester Bay, a historic seaside village and important fishing and shipping center, attracted many painters, including Winslow Homer and Childe Hassam.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

extended_text.content:
Maurice Brazil Prendergast

Glimpse of the Harbor, Gloucester, about 1916-1919

watercolor over pencil on paper

13 ¼ x 10 in.

Gift of the Gamboliers

Learn More

Maurice Prendergast was born in Newfoundland, Canada. When his father’s business failed, the family came to Boston where he was apprenticed to a commercial artist.  He studied in Paris at the Académie Colarossi and the Académie Julian.  Prendergast became a member of the group of American painters known as The Eight, who included Robert Henri, Everett Shinn, John Sloan, Arthur B. Davies, Ernest Lawson, George Luks, and William Glackens.  Prendergast was considered a post-impressionist because of his use of simplified forms, flat areas of boldly contrasted colors and rhythmically, decorative patterning.  His complex arrangements have been described as tapestry-like or resembling mosaics.  Unlike the Ashcan School members of The Eight, Prendergast favored people involved in leisure activities rather than gritty, urban scenes. Prendergast earned considerable attention (but meager sales) for his watercolors and oils depicting bustling crowds.  He is remembered today as one of the first Americans to adopt the ideas of Cézanne and turn them into his personal interpretation of Post-Impressionism.  Prendergast’s brother Charles was an important frame maker whose frames can often be seen on his brother’s work.

In Glimpse of the Harbor, Gloucester, Prendergast handles this watercolor view of the Massachusetts harbor with typical freedom, wielding thin washes in loosely knit strokes and allowing broad areas of the white paper to figure in the composition. Patterns contrast between rigid geometry and curvilinear forms.  The people are characteristically blended into the scene so they do not disturb the rhythm of the composition.

Reference

Richard J. Wattenmaker.  Maurice Prendergast, New York: Harry N Abrams, 1994. ISBN-13: 978-0810937260
extended_text.title: Urban Realism

36352.title: Safety, Danger, Relationships
36352.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in honor of Mr. Budd Stalnaker
36352.medium_support: wool, linen, buttons, copper wire and silk

extended_text.content:
Artist’s Statement

Antecedents for these materials are Tlingit button blankets I saw in the Pacific Northwest and African garments with beads and buttons. A green cross has been used in the United States as a symbol relating to industrial safety. I wanted to appropriate this symbol in attaching the buttons and have it evoke issues of risk, such as rape awareness, domestic violence, HIV transmission, and things that bombard us on a daily basis. The field, consisting of black and blue buttons positioned in the form of an equilateral cross, suggests our field of safe, secure, and significant relationships.

-Budd Stalnaker
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

30430.title: day dress
30430.description: printed cotton faille, with appliqued cut-out flowers; red, green, orange folliage on cream ground
30430.provenance: Betty Furness (19161994), New York; through (Stan Weaver, New York); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art (1985).

extended_text.content: This lavish summer day dress features a fitted sleeveless bodice with a modified scoop neckline, which is lower in the back than in the front. The neckline and armholes are adorned with appliquéd cut-out flowers, a feature that was often seen in garments by Chanel and other French couturiers of the time. A crisp single layer petticoat with horsehair supports the bouffant skirt. The hourglass silhouette is reminiscent of Dior’s New Look, which he introduced in 1947.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

30430.exhibit_history:
An American Legacy: Norell, Blass, Halston & Sprouse
Paul Textile and Fashion Arts galleries, IMA
May 4, 2012 - January 27, 2013

2732.title: Clipper Ship
2732.inscription: inscribed, signed, and dated L.R.: 17/56 - Crutchfield - 67

extended_text.content:
"Underlying Crutchfield's art is the belief that man's mechanical feats in the period from 1840 to 1914 mark a true summit of human achievement, but the attitude that accompanied these feats was nonetheless absurd. He is constantly poking fun at man's innocent faith in technology."
-Jerry Muller, 1972
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

2735.title: Covered Wagons
2735.inscription: inscribed, signed, and dated below image L.R.: 17/56-Crutchfield-67

extended_text.content:
Crutchfield, who relocated to California in 1967, was among the first artists his old acquaintance Ken Tyler invited to make lithographs at Gemini G.E.L. in Los Angeles.

"The Americana series reflects my early interest in the landscape of the Southwest and early American transportation technology. The vehicles are pictured as stranded, hung up or marooned . . . I am not making social commentary about whether a man should not make machines, but rather I am watching the passing parade of the irony of existence itself."
-William Crutchfield
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

32155.title: ball gown
32155.title_notes: A) bodice B) skirt C) shawl
32155.description: pink and peach silk and lace ballgown
32155.credit_line: Gift of Mary Louise Milliken Landers and Ruth Bybee Milliken Murphy in memory of their mother, Mary Addison Bybee Milliken
32155.provenance: Mary Addison Bybee Miliken, Boston; Mary Louise Milliken Landers, Ruth Bybee Milliken Murphy, Connecticut; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art (June 20, 1996).
32155.dimensions:
A) bodice: length 17-3/4 in.
B) skirt: length: 39 in.
C) shawl 41 x 43 in.

extended_text.content: This beautifully crafted ball gown was made by Louis Valentine of Boston, one of the most fashionable dressmakers of the time. Even though a few designer-dressmakers were active in the Midwest, it was very common for stylish women of Indiana to have their wedding gowns and trousseaus made by famous tailoring shops on the East Coast.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

32155.exhibit_history: FOR EXHIBITIONS AND ROTATIONS DISPLAYED ON SITE AT THE IMA OR ON TOUR BY THE IMA, SEE THE EVENTS TAB.

37316.title: wedding dress
37316.description: A wedding dress in two pieces made from an off-white silk plain weave (predominately warp-faced and quite loosely woven compared to the taffeta) and silk chiffon over a base of silk taffeta.  The bodice has a low "boat" neckline trimmed lavishly with swags of chiffon and lace and is in the "pouter pigeon" bustline style of the period.
37316.medium_support: silk plain weave, silk taffeta, silk chiffon, lace, cotton
37316.provenance: Peter Stewart, Indianapolis; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art (September 15, 1994).
37316.dimensions:
A) bodice (shoulder to waist): L: 17 in. 
B) skirt (waist to hem): L: 54 in.
37316.exhibit_history:
I Do: The Marriage of Art and Fashion
Paul Textile and Fashion Arts Galleries
June 6, 2006 - April 22, 2007

32253.title: wedding dress, chemise, train, veil
32253.description: cream and white silk velvet chemise wedding gown with train, embroidered with pearls and rhinestones
32253.credit_line: Gift of Mrs. G. Vance Smith
32253.medium_support: silk velvet, silk chiffon, silk satin, linen lace, silk net, glass pearls and rhinestones
32253.provenance: Mrs. G. Vance Smith, Indianapolis; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art (October 2, 1975).

extended_text.content:
In the 1920s the fashionable silhouette was often shapeless and tubular. The waistline was dropped and the hemline was raised. Even though the "flapper" style did not emerge until 1926, the dresses from the 1920s are referred to as "flapper style."

It is often assumed that all dresses were short during the '20s. However, skirts were at their shortest length only between 1926 and 1928, when the whole leg, up to the knee, was exposed. By 1929, uneven hems and asymmetrical hemlines helped the transition to longer skirts.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

32253.exhibit_history:
I Do: The Marriage of Art and Fashion
Paul Textile and Fashion Arts Galleries
June 6, 2006 - April 22, 2007

2665.description: handmade Venetiran point lace in ecru; sleeves trimmed with wide ruffle of pleated silk organza, ties around the neck, with white silk taffeta lining

14981.title: dress
14981.description: White Venetian point lace bodice (a) and skirt (b).  Bodice all lace lined in white China silk, high boned collar, leg-o-mutton sleeves.  Skirt of soft silk with lace insets; fully lined with taffeta.
14981.credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Ralph C. Vonnegut
14981.medium_support: lace and china silk, fully lined with taffeta
14981.provenance: Mrs. Ralph C. Vonnegut, Indianapolis, Indiana; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art, December 1970.

28349.title: dress
28349.description: challlis- small floral print, rose, green on ivory. Basque, all hand stitching. Opening at center front
28349.credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Howard A. Spruill
28349.provenance: Mr. and Mrs. Howard A. Spruill, Wyncote, Pennsylvania; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art (December 1970).

extended_text.content:
The fabric of this dress was most likely produced in England. The highly stylized floral motif possibly represents roses. The pattern mimics a type of design where the motif is meant to be blurred.

The hourglass silhouette of this dress is achieved by a tightly corseted waist. As many as six layers of petticoats would have been worn under the skirt to achieve fullness. The large puffed sleeves further accentuate the hourglass shape. These impractical and flamboyant sleeves were commonly known as gigot or leg-o-mutton, because of their similarity to sheep’s hind legs.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

28349.exhibit_history:
Fashion in Bloom
Paul Fashion Arts Gallery
April 4, 2009 - January 31, 2010

16826.title: I've Got an Ace Up My Sleeve
16826.credit_line: Mary V. Black Art Endowment Fund
16826.medium_support: hand-painted and hand-appliqued cotton with machine quilting

extended_text.content:
Everything in the black family either happens in church or around the dinner table. In our house every other Saturday my dad and three uncles would get together to play poker, while the women would "visit" with each other in another room.
The poker players took their game very seriously. Each would try to bluff the other into thinking that he held the better hand. In the quilt each man is looking at the other with suspicion. Each would chide the other by saying, "I've got an ace up my sleeve."
The quilt is also my way of honoring my father, who brought much laughter into our home when I was a child.
-Carolyn Mazloomi
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

16826.exhibit_history:
Stitch by Stitch: A Quilt Potpourri
January 10 - August 4, 1996.

6151.title: dress
6151.creation_notes: Could be American, French or English
6151.description:
two piece dress with elaborate black and white Japanizism print- Emperor's crysanthimum, leg-o mutton sleeves and a bell shaped skirt
a) bodice
b) skirt
6151.credit_line: Gift of Mrs William H. Jungclaus
6151.provenance: Mrs. William H. Jungclaus, Indianapolis; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art (September 19, 1974).

extended_text.content:
The chrysanthemums covering the entire surface of the fabric of this dress make it a fine example of Japonisme, which referred to the influence of Japanese art on Western art and culture and described the craze for things Japanese in the last quarter of the 1800s.

After 1890 the bustle disappeared, and the new skirt styles were flared smoothly over the hip and then gradually widened at the hemline. By 1895 the leg-o-mutton sleeves had swelled to gigantic proportions. Tiny waists were further emphasized by the hourglass silhouettes that resulted through the balance between the width of the skirt and the volume of the sleeves.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

6151.exhibit_history: FOR EXHIBITIONS AND ROTATIONS DISPLAYED ON SITE AT THE IMA OR ON TOUR BY THE IMA, SEE THE EVENTS TAB.

30796.title: skirt suit
30796.title_notes: D) hat found by original donor, gifted, and accessioned in 2013
30796.description: pale pink wool tweed suit; knee length pencil skirt with long sleeve three-buttoned jacket, pink silk blouse and lining, hat
30796.provenance: Mrs. W. Paul Zimmerman, Jr., Indianapolis; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art (September 18, 1980).
30796.inscription: Bill Blass for Maurice Rentner / Davidson's Atlanta

extended_text.content:
This three-piece suit exhibits the strong influence of Chanel’s simple yet elegant designs on American fashion. In 1954 Gabrielle “Coco” Chanel reissued her trademark three-piece suit, consisting of a cardigan-style jacket and an A-line skirt with a matching blouse. Blass, like Chanel, designed with the modern woman in mind, creating easy-to-wear, timeless classics with refined detailing.

In 1959 Bill Blass became head designer at Maurice Rentner, who at the time was one of the most respected businessmen in the New York fashion scene. An early example of Blass’s work, the fully lined pink wool tweed jacket has quilted lapels and attached cuffs, which provides the illusion of a long-sleeved blouse worn underneath. The matching pink silk blouse, however, is actually a fitted sleeveless shell with an attached tie.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

30796.exhibit_history:
An American Legacy; Norell, Blass, Halston & Sprouse
May 4, 2012 - January 27, 2013
Paul Textile and Fashion Arts Galleries

58281.title: evening dress
58281.provenance: David W. Campbell, New York (Stan Weaver, New York); given to IMA September 20, 1984.

extended_text.content:
Halston said, "Chiffon is the most beautiful feminine fabric for women of every age."

The halter bodice of this dramatic evening dress is constructed of four layers of chiffon. The petal skirt is constructed with three layers of doubled chiffon in a sarong wrap, revealing the leg several inches above the knee in the front and dropping to the floor in back.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

58281.exhibit_history:
Simply Halston
Paul Fashion Arts Gallery, IMA
April 13, 2008 - January 4, 2009

60855.title: evening ensemble (genie outfit)
60855.description: blue two piece ensemble with rhinestones
60855.credit_line: Mr. and Mrs. William B. Ansted Jr. Art Fund
60855.provenance: Doyle New York, sale April 9, 2003, (0304091) lot 581; purchased by the Indianapolis Museum of Art (2003).

extended_text.content:
The influence of 1960s popular culture on the world of fashion affected even the most conservative designers, such as Norman Norell.

This "genie" outfit in electric blue, with a bare midriff top, was inspired by the popular hit TV program of the time "I Dream of Genie."
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

60855.exhibit_history:
All Dressed Up: The Latest Additions
March 31-December 30, 2007
Paul Textile Gallery, Indianapolis Museum of Art

35150.title: dress
35150.description: One-piece. Rose silk and gray velvet brocade with front and lower part of skirt and trimmings of rose colored satin. Lace at neck.
35150.credit_line: Gift of Mrs. A. L. Lockridge
35150.provenance: Mrs. A. L. Lockridge through Belle Lockridge; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art May 16, 1944.

extended_text.content:
The voided silk velvet fabric, with its pattern of stylized roses, complements the graceful draping of the vibrantly colored silk satin fabric of this dress.

Between 1908 and 1918 clothing styles gradually changed to reflect the new century and new women. Waistlines were raised, and longer and straighter corsets replaced the S-shaped ones. The corset—almost reaching below the thighs—helped achieve tubular, slimmer silhouettes. These columnar sheath dresses were reminiscent of the fashion of the early 1800s. The hemlines rose in this period to reveal the ankles.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

35150.exhibit_history: FOR EXHIBITIONS AND ROTATIONS DISPLAYED ON SITE AT THE IMA OR ON TOUR BY THE IMA, SEE THE EVENTS TAB.

18831.title: petticoat
18831.description: hand made linen and cotton petticoat with hand Valenciennes lace, built-up and  embroidered batiste in Art Nouveau motif
18831.credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Martin S. Kochman
18831.provenance: Mrs. Martin S. Kochman, Indianapolis; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art (September 19, 1974).

51.title: dress
51.description: floor length, silk chiffon dress with hand rolled neck line, Matisse - inspired floral print
51.provenance: Dr. Robert Failey, Indianapolis; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art June 14, 1974.

extended_text.content:
Roses, hibiscus, fleabane and bird-of-paradise flowers are depicted on the fabric of this dress. Thurn, an exclusive high-end fashion store in New York City, was famous for offering European dresses as well as creating well-made American fashions.

The uneven hems and asymmetrical hemlines of 1929 served as the transition from the shorter hems of the flapper era to the longer skirts of the 1930s. As hemlines began to fall, waistlines, which had dropped to the hip, returned to their natural position. The boyish look of the 1920s gave way to the more feminine styles of the ’30s.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

51.exhibit_history: FOR EXHIBITIONS AND ROTATIONS DISPLAYED ON SITE AT THE IMA OR ON TOUR BY THE IMA, SEE THE EVENTS TAB.

10359.title: cape
10359.creation_notes: English or American?- because of interlining
10359.description: black silk velvet cape with glass beads covering surface- batwing sleeves and cacoon shape
10359.credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Marks in memory of Mrs. M. A. Isaacs
10359.medium_support: silk velvet, metallic fabric, glass beads : silk taffeta lining
10359.provenance: Mrs. M. A. Isaacs, Indianapolis; Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Marks; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art (March 20, 1980).

13361.title: dress
13361.description: red voided velvet dress with cartridge pleating
13361.credit_line: Gift of Stanlet E. Weaver in memory of Norman Norell
13361.provenance: Stan Weaver, New York; Indianapolis Museum of Art (September 18 1980).

extended_text.content:
Egret flowers are scattered over the surface of this brilliant red dress. The elongated fitted bodice is achieved through a dropped waistline. The cartridge pleats along the top of the skirt not only create fullness, but also serve as a decorative element.

The design of the dress was probably influenced by Christian Dior’s H-line, which was introduced in 1954. Dior’s aim was to push the bust up as high as possible and drop the waist to the hips, which formed the crossbar of the letter H.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

13361.exhibit_history: FOR EXHIBITIONS AND ROTATIONS DISPLAYED ON SITE AT THE IMA OR ON TOUR BY THE IMA, SEE THE EVENTS TAB.

19519.title: evening dress
19519.description: pink strapeless ball gown; Ballerina style
19519.medium_support: silk taffeta and net trimmed with machine lace, pearls, sequins and glass beads
19519.provenance: Shirley Marco Kulwin, Indianapolis; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art (1980).

32531.title: coat
32531.description: beige wool twill weave coat with black buttons and exagerrated collar
32531.credit_line: Gift of Mrs. John E. Miklozek
32531.provenance: purchased at L.S.Ayres department store, Indianapolis early 1950s; Mrs. John Miklozek, Terre Haute, Indiana; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art (1980).

extended_text.content: Beautifully conceived and well-constructed coats were important and reoccurring in Norell’s work. One of Norell’s classic looks is the cape-collared coat. As was typical of late 1960s styles, the oversized collar resembles a capelet. The shape of the coat follows the contour of the body and calls attention to the upper part of the torso, which is gracefully rounded to stand away from the neck—a feature that became a hallmark of his designs.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

32531.exhibit_history: FOR EXHIBITIONS AND ROTATIONS DISPLAYED ON SITE AT THE IMA OR ON TOUR BY THE IMA, SEE THE EVENTS TAB.

27664.title: coat
27664.description: black cotton velvet coat with silver bugle beads machine embroidery
27664.credit_line: Gift of Mrs. John E. Miklozek
27664.provenance: Mrs. John E. Miklozek, Terre Haute, Indiana; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art (September 18, 1980).
27664.inscription: Bill Blass for Maurice Rentner / L.S. Ayres, Indianapolis

extended_text.content: Blass, perennially inspired by the male wardrobe, tailored this piece in lush machine-embroidered velvet, embellished with silver bugle bead trim. The coat is constructed with a Nehru collar, a component borrowed from Indian fashion, and the fabric used recalls Indian or Mughal influence. Further illustrating the impact of non-Western styles on his design, Blass pads the hemline, which is a construction detail frequently seen in kimonos.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

27664.exhibit_history:
An American Legacy; Norell, Blass, Halston & Sprouse
Paul Textile and Fashion Arts Galleries, IMA
May 4, 2012 - January 27, 2013

32034.title: evening dress
32034.provenance: David W. Campbell,  New York (Stan Weaver, New York); given to IMA July 14, 1980.

extended_text.content:
Halston's silk chiffon serapes were seemingly shapeless and caressed the body. This one of a kind tie-dyed serepe is a more sophisticated version of the prevalent trend from the sixties and seventies

 

The tie-dye print of this serepe was designed with the shape of the garment in mind. Traditionally these garments were worn over loose fitting pajama pants or on their own. For those who dared, nothing was worn underneath, but for those more modest, Halston constructed a tiny chiffon bra to be worn underneath.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

32034.exhibit_history:
Simply Halston
Paul Fashion Arts Gallery, IMA
April 13, 2008 - January 4, 2009

932.title: evening dress
932.description: red, green and white dress; gathers for bust darts, puff blouse, new look kind of skirt, some staining on the sleeves, resist dyed warp, painted on the loom
932.provenance: purchased at L.S.Ayres department store, Indianapolis early 1950s; Mrs. Robert Seastorm, Indianapolis; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art (1980).

35321.title: coat
35321.description: silk velvet lined with silk satin and trimmed with metallic wraped thread in geometric pattering
35321.credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Otto N. Frenzel
35321.provenance: Mrs. Otto N. Fenzel, Carmel, Indiana; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art (September 17, 1981).

26725.title: evening dress
26725.description: red floor length silk taffeta and chiffon dress with balloon sleeves and large bow at waistline
26725.credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Ronald Reagan and Bill Blass
26725.provenance: Bill Blass, New York (designer); Nancy Davis Reagan (born Anne Frances Robbins on July 6, 1921); through Bill Blass William Ralph "Bill" Blass (June 22, 1922  June 12, 2002); given to Indianapolis Museum of Art (May 20, 1982).

extended_text.content:
First Lady Nancy Reagan originally wore this evening dress on May 7, 1981, at a state dinner for Zenko Suzuki, the prime minister of Japan, and his wife, Sachi Suzuki. The gown was worn again on the occasion of the first state dinner for the then-new president of Egypt, Hosni Mubarak, and his wife, Suzanne Mubarak, on February 3, 1982. It was donated to the IMA later that year.

One of Mrs. Reagan’s favorite designers, Blass was renowned for his ability to cleverly combine unexpected textures in luxurious eveningwear. By juxtaposing delicate chiffon and lustrous taffeta, both dyed “Reagan” red, Blass created a dress that perfectly captures the popular silhouette of the 1980s. The large pouf sleeves created a dramatic yet slimming effect, while the large bow at the waistline added balance to Mrs. Reagan’s petite frame.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

26725.exhibit_history: FOR EXHIBITIONS AND ROTATIONS DISPLAYED ON SITE AT THE IMA OR ON TOUR BY THE IMA, SEE THE EVENTS TAB: Bill Blass, An American Designer, Indiana University Art Museum, Bloomington, Indiana, 10/2002-12/2002, exhibition curated by Kathleen Rowold of the Elizabeth Sage Historic Costume Collection at Indiana Univeristy
